Inner-pore reduction nucleation of palladium nanoparticles in highly conductive wurster-type covalent organic frameworks for efficient oxygen reduction electrocatalysis Weiwen Wang Lu Zhang Tianping Wang Zhen Zhang Xiangnan Wang Chong Cheng ⁎ Xikui Liu ⁎ College of Polymer Science and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China College of Polymer Science and Engineering State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu 610065 Sichuan China College of Polymer Science and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract An in-situ redox deposition strategy was adopted to grow uniform palladium nanoparticles in highly conductive Kagome covalent organic frameworks to enhance the activity of oxygen reduction reaction. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have emerged as a class of promising supports for electrocatalysis because of their advantages including good crystallinity, highly ordered pores, and structural diversity. However, their poor conductivity represents the main obstruction to their practical application. Here, we reported a novel synthesis strategy for synergistically endowing a triphenylamine-based COFs with improved electrical conductivity and excellent catalytic activity for oxygen reduction, via the in-situ redox deposition and confined growth of palladium nanoparticles inside the porous structure of COFs using reductive triphenylamine frameworks as reducing agent; meanwhile, the triphenylamine unit was oxidized to radical cation structure and affords radical cation COFs with conductivity as high as 3.2*10−1 S m−1. Such a uniform confine palladium nanoparticle on highly conductive COFs makes it an efficient electrocatalyst for four-electron oxygen reduction reaction (4e-ORR), showing excellent activities and fast kinetics with a remarkable half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.865 V and an ultralow Tafel slope of 39.7 mV dec−1 in alkaline media even in the absence of extra commercial conductive fillers. The generality of this strategy was proved by preparing the different metal and metal alloy nanoparticles supported on COFs (Au@COF, Pt@COF, AuPd@COF, AgPd@COF, and PtPd@COF) using reductive triphenylamine frameworks as reducing agent. This work not only provides a facile strategy for the fabrication of highly conductive COF supported ORR electrocatalysts, but also sheds new light on the practical application of Zn-air battery. Keywords Covalent organic frameworks Wurster-type structure In-situ reduction nucleation Palladium nanoparticles Oxygen reduction electrocatalysis 1 Introduction Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is of great importance for energy storage and conversion technologies, including fuel cells and metal-air batteries [1–5]. A highly active electrocatalyst is the key to these electrochemical applications. However, ORR suffered sluggish kinetics involving four sequential proton-coupled electron transfer steps [6–9]. Noble metals (Pt, Pd, Ir, Ru) are normally good electrocatalysts for these applications with extremely high half-wave potential due to their distinct electronic structure [10–14]. Although Pt-based electrocatalysts have shown excellent ORR activity due to their intrinsic properties, their large-scale utilization has been greatly limited by easy poisoning issues of Pt during ORR catalysis process [15,16]. Palladium-based catalysts, with better anti-CO poisoning, have received increasing attention as potential replacements for Pt-based materials for ORR due to their similarity to Pt in electronic configuration and chemical properties [17–22]. However, low noble metal utilization efficiency and sluggish ORR kinetics lead to the high cost or huge consumption of noble metals. To solve this problem, an attractive strategy is to disperse ultrafine noble metal nanoparticle catalysts on appropriate scaffolds with large surface areas and highly ordered pores; accordingly, low content of electroactive metals can make full advantages of noble metals. Various porous materials such as active carbon [23], N-doped carbon [24,25], mesoporous carbon [26,27], metal–organic frameworks [28,29], and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [30] have been explored as the supporter for noble metal nanoparticles to enhance their activity and stability. COFs as crystalline porous polymers with highly ordered pores and highly accessible surface areas, have been regarded as one of the most potential scaffolds for anchoring catalytic metal nanoparticles [31–35]. Furthermore, the nitrogen-rich frameworks endow COFs with more advantages to be the ideal supports to upload active catalytic species for catalysis [36–38]. So far, various polycrystalline COFs materials have been proven versatile in the dispersion and confined growth of metal nanoparticles (NPs) to a narrow size distribution through metal coordination sites in the COFs skeleton. And the resulting metal NPs@COFs have shown significantly improved catalytic activity and stability in catalysis [30,39–42]. Albeit the progress achieved in fabricating COFs-supported noble metal NPs for ORR electrocatalysis, to the best of our knowledge, the development of this field is still elusive and largely underexplored, which is far lower than that of carbon-supported noble metal electrocatalytic materials. There are two main bottlenecks for the COFs to become substrates for noble metal-based electrocatalysis [31,32,41,43]. First, in the preparation process of NPs-embedded COFs, the reduction of metal ions does not have to occur in the pores of COFs material resulting from the randomness of the reduction reaction, where the metal ions can be directly reduced to metal NPs in solution. Currently, the reduction of NPs is uncontrolled and tends to grow into large-diameter morphologies with extremely low exposed active areas, then leading to the poor catalytic efficiency, which greatly decreases the utilization rate of precious metals. It is a great challenge to make the reduction of metal ions occur in the pores of COF materials with high selectivity. Another bottleneck to developing high-efficiency metal NPs@COFs electrocatalysts concerns the intrinsic poor conductivity stemmed from COFs scaffolds. The efficient flow of electrons is crucial for the electrocatalysis process, most of the COFs possess poorer conductivity than that of metal, metal oxide, or carbon materials. As a result, the catalytic activity of most COFs supported noble metal electrocatalysts is much lower than that of carbon-based electrocatalysts, mainly because of the charge-transfer limitation caused by the insulating nature of the COFs matrix in the electrocatalytic process. Thus, most synthesis routes to COFs-supported catalysts necessitate high-temperature pyrolysis to enhance their conductivity, which may lead to undesirable porous changes and uncertain electrical doping sites. In this respect, developing pyrolysis-free porous material-derived electrocatalysts with well-defined structures and predictable active sites is attracting interest and is essential, but it still remains challenging. Herein, we innovatively reported a new synthetic strategy to solve the above two bottlenecks through simultaneously immobilizing highly dispersed Pd NPs and introducing a highly conductive COFs matrix using highly conductive radical cation COFs. Both two porous COFs (named WTA-COF and WOTA-COF) are highly crystalline and form a Kagome lattice through the condensation of the N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis(4-aminophenyl)-1,4-phenylenediamine (Wurster type tetraamine) with terephthalaldehyde or 2,5-dimethoxy-1,4-benzenedicarboxaldehyde. The most important feature of this Wurster-type tetraamine monomer is that it contains phenylenediamine unit moiety, which can act as a strong reducing agent and promotes reduction [44–47]. So, when the as-prepared WTA-COF and WOTA-COF were immersed in palladium solution, the in-situ redox reaction occurred between reductive phenylenediamine unit and adsorbed palladium ions, which resulted in the formation of ultrafine and uniform Pd NPs and confined growth of Pd NPs inside the porous structure of COFs (Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF). Due to the reductive phenylenediamine units being the linker of COF, the palladium reduction can occur inside the pores and surface of COFs, and cannot happen in the solution. More interesting, after in-situ reduction of palladium, the phenylenediamine units were oxidized to radical cation; both palladium species and radical cation afford radical cation COFs with conductivity as high as 3.2*10−1 S m−1. Furthermore, the spontaneous in situ reduction method prevent the aggregation of Pd NPs and expose more active sites, increasing the interaction between Pd species and COFs supports, which would improve ORR performance. Such a uniform confine palladium NPs on highly conductive COF make it an efficient electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) with Pd@WTA-COF showed a high half-wave potential of 0.865 V even in the absence of adding extra commercial conductive fillers. Moreover, the performance only slightly decreased after running for 20,000 s, thus conformed to their excellent stability. Our work provides a novel and simple strategy to directly fabricate metal NPs uniformly distributed in highly conductive COFs with superior electrochemical performance for energy storage and conversion applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials N,N,N',N'-tetrakis (4-aminophenyl)-1,4-benzenediamine (Wurster type tetraamine, 97%), terephthalaldehyde (98%), Mesitylene (≥99%) and Palladium(II) acetate (≥99%, Pd: 47%) were purchased from Adamas. 2,5-dimethoxy-1,4-benzenedicarboxaldehyde (98%) were used as received from Zhengzhou Alfa Chemical Co., ltd. Dioxane, Benzyl Alcohol, N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF), Tetrahydrofuran (THF), and 36% Acetic acid were purchased from Chengdu KELONG Chemical Co., ltd. Carbon cloth (WOS1009) was purchased from CeTech Co., ltd. All chemicals were analytical grade and used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of pristine WTA-COF At first, a mixture of Wurster-type tetraamine (12 mg, 0.025 mmol) and terephthalaldehyde (TA) (6.8 mg, 0.05 mmol) was suspended in 1 mL mesitylene plus 1 mL benzyl alcohol, then stirred for 15 min. After 0.05 mL 36% acetic acid was added, the above mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and maintained at 100 °C for 72 h. The resulting dark red suspension was filtrated and washed with DMF, THF and DI-water three times, respectively. After that, the precipitates were freeze-dried for 12 h, and then the WTA-COF was obtained. 2.3 Synthesis of pristine WOTA-COF Wurster type tetraamine (23.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), 1,4-Benzenedicarboxaldehyde,2,5-dimethoxy ((OMe)2TA) (19.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) were suspended in 0.3 mL mesitylene and 0.3 mL dioxane, and stirred 15 min. Subsequently, 0.1 mL 36% acetic acid was added. Then the mixed solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and maintained at 120 °C for 72 h. The resulting dark red suspension was filtrated and washed with DMF, THF and DI-water three times, respectively. Finally, WOTA-COF was obtained after the plum precipitates were freeze-dried for 12 h. 2.4 Synthesis of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF through in-situ reduction of palladium salt In a typical synthesis, 20 mg Pd(OAc)2, 20 mg COFs (WTA-COF or WOTA-COF) powder and 10 mL ethanol were mixed in a glass vial, then ultrasonicated for 2 h at room temperature to yield a homogeneous solution. After filtration, the obtained sample was washed with ethanol and dried under a vacuum. the reaction equation was provided as follows: 2.5 Preparation of COF on carbon cloths (COF/CC) through dissolution–recrystallization process Commercial carbon cloth (CC) was immersed in 200 mL 30 wt% H2O2 and kept at 50 °C for 24 h. Then the CC was taken out, washed thoroughly with distilled water, and dried in a vacuum at 60 °C for 5 h. The 30% H2O2-treated carbon cloth (CC) and 30 mg obtained COFs were dispersed in the solvent system used in COFs synthesis (benzyl alcohol / trimethylbenzene for WTA-COF and dioxane / trimethylbenzene for WOTA-COF) and added 0.3 mL 36% acetic acid as catalyst. Then the above mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and maintained at 100 °C (for WTA-COF/CC) or 120 °C (for WOTA-COF/CC) for 72 h. For the synthesis of Pd@COF/CC, the COF/CC was immersed in a Pd(OAc)2 acetonitrile solution. After 2 h, the carbon cloth was washed several times with ethanol and then dried under vacuum to obtain Pd@COF/CC. 2.6 Characterizations Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were measured with a Nicolet 560 spectrometer (Nicolet Instrument Technologies, Madison, WI, USA). The morphologies and microstructural analyses were studied using scanning electron microscopy (FEI, Eindhoven, The Netherlands) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Talos F200X). Powder Xray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded at room temperature on an X′Pert Pro MPD diffractometer (PANalytical B.V., Almelo, the Netherlands) with Cu Kα radiation at 30 kV and 15 mA, from 2θ = 1.5–35° with the scanning rate of 2° min−1. The X-ray photoelectric spectroscopic (XPS) characterization was carried out on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+ (Thermo Fisher), and Al Kα X-ray (6 mA, 12 kV) was utilized as the irradiation source. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K using a Tristar system; the surface area was calculated from the adsorption data using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore distributions were obtained from the adsorption branch using the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method. The solid-state NMR experiments have been carried out in AVANCE III 500 MHz at a magnetic field of 11.746 T equipped with a triple channel 2.5 mm magic-angel spinning (MAS) probe-head. The electrical conductivities of the materials were measured at room temperature using a Resistivity Tester (Four Probe Method, ST2722SD+ST2643). 2.7 Electrochemical characterizations All electrochemical measurements were performed on 0.1 M KOH electrolyte in a typical three-electrode system on an electrochemical station (Gamry), with the graphite rod and Ag/AgCl as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively, and a glassy carbon electrode (GCE, diameter: 5 mm, electrode area: ∼0.196 cm2) loaded with catalyst as the working electrode. All the potentials reported in this work were presented with iR corrections, which were calibrated to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to E (RHE) = E (Ag/AgCl) + 0.197 V + 0.059 × pH. V in 0.1 M KOH. For the preparation of the working electrode, catalysts (5 mg) were dispersed in 0.5 wt% Nafion (500 μL), and the resulting mixture was sonicated for 2 h at room temperature to form a homogeneous catalysts ink. Then, 5 μL of the ink was pipetted onto the GCE disk to form a catalyst layer and dried at room temperature (the catalyst loading was ∼0.25 mg cm−2). ORR activity was proved by the electrochemical measurements of linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), cyclic voltammetry (CV), and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), which were carried out using a rotating disk electrode (RDE). CV curves were recorded within a potential of –0.46 – 1.04 V vs RHE at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 after the electrolyte was purged with O2 for at least 30 min. Before recording, several fast CV (100 mV s−1) were recorded to stabilize the catalyst. LSV curves were measured in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolytes with the rotating speed from 2400 r min−1 to 400 r min−1 with a sweep rate of 10 mV s−1, and the potential region is 1 V to 0.04 V vs RHE. The Tafel plot was calculated by the result of LSV with a sweep rate of 10 mV s−1 and a rotating speed of 1600 r min−1. The electron transfer number was calculated by the different LSV results using the Koutecky–Levich (K–L) equations. 1 J = 1 J K + 1 J L = 1 J K + 1 B ω 1 / 2 B = 0.2 n FC 0 ( D 0 ) 2 / 3 v 1 / 6 Where J is the measured current density, J K, and J L represent the kinetic and the diffusion-limiting current density, respectively; ω is the rotating rate of the electrode; B is determined by the slop of the K–L plots; F is the Faraday constant (96,485C mol−1); C0 is the dissolved concentration of O2 (1.2*10−6 mol cm−3); D0 is the diffusion coefficient of O2 (1.9*10−5 cm2 s−1); v is the kinetic viscosity of the electrolyte (0.01 cm2 s−1). 3 Results and discussion WTA-COF and WOTA-COF were synthesized under solvothermal reaction by condensing N,N,N',N'-tetrakis (4-aminophenyl)-1,4-benzenediamine (Wurster) with terephthalaldehyde (TA) or 2,5-dimethoxy 1,4-Benzenedicarboxaldehyde ((OMe)2TA), respectively (Fig. 1 a). The results of PXRD, for both WTA-COF and WOTA-COF, show sharp reflections peaks with 2θ approximately at 2.4°, 4.2°, 4.8°, 6.4° and 8.7°, which are assigned to the (100), (110), (200), (210) and (310) planes, respectively [45–47]. Simultaneously, the theoretical structural simulations were used to determine the crystal structure of two types of COFs (Fig. 1b and c, and Fig. S1). Pawley refinement of the PXRD pattern for full profile fitting against the proposed models provides a P6-symmetric structure model with a unit cell of a = b = 43.1 Å and c = 4.48 Å, α = β = 90° and γ = 120° (Rwp = 6.64% and Rp = 5.33%) for WTA-COF; and the unit cell parameters of WOTA-COF were a = b = 45.1 Å, c = 4.50 Å, and α = β = 90° and γ = 120° (Rwp = 4.73% and Rp = 3.99%), which is consistent with experimental test data. The porous nature of the WOTA-COF and WTA-COF was investigated by a N2 sorption experiment at 77 K with a micropore option, and pore size distribution was calculated by NLDFT modeling based on N2 adsorption data. As shown in Fig. 1(d), the overall isotherm is a combination of type-I isotherms, indicating both microporous and mesoporous characteristics as expected in the Kagome type structure. And the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area of WTA-COF and WOTA-COF powder was calculated to be 589 m2 g−1 and 836 m2 g−1 (Fig. 1d), and the pore size was 2.05 nm and 2.79 nm (Fig. S2), respectively. The high BET surface area and large total pore volume strongly support the porous nature of COFs. The above results of PXRD and BET demonstrate that the porous and highly crystalline COFs structures were obtained. To further confirm the structural information of COFs, Fourier transforms infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and 13C Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) were carried out for WTA-COF and WOTA-COF. As depicted in Fig. S3, for both WTA-COF and WOTA-COF, the successful preparation of the Schiff base structure was corroborated by the emerging characteristic peak of the −C=N-stretching vibrational peak (1666 cm−1 for WTA-COF, and 1670 cm−1 for WOTA-COF), and the disappearance of the −NH2-stretching vibrational peaks at 3348 cm−1 and 3366 cm−1 in the Wurster monomer. These FTIR data indicate the complete conversion from molecular building blocks to COFs. All peaks in the solid-state 13C NMR spectra of WTA-COF and WOTA-COF are marked in the indicated groups of the inset chemical structure. The resonance signals at 159, 145 and 128 ppm can be assigned to imine linkage, −C−N− and carbons on the benzene ring, respectively, in WTA-COF (Fig. 1e). Similarly, the main characteristic peaks in 13C CP-MAS spectrum of WOTA-COF can also be assigned (Fig. 1f). All above results confirmed the occurrence of Schiff base reactions, and the successful synthesis of highly crystalline, high BET surface area and large total pore volume COFs. The morphologies of the obtained COFs were assessed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM), where the WTA-COF was composed of microcrystalline nanosheets with ∼45 nm in thickness (Fig. 2 b); and the WOTA-COF displays the similar nanosheets (Fig. 2d). The crystalline structures of WTA-COF and WOTA-COF were visualized by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). The clear lattice fringes of (200), (310) and (210) crystal faces were shown in Fig. 2(c and e) for both WTA-COF and WOTA-COF, further confirming the simulated crystal structure (Fig. 1b and c). The as-synthesized WTA-COF and WOTA-COF have intrinsic reductive triarylamine structures with restricted pore channels, and the palladium-based ORR catalysts are widely investigated due to their similar electron configuration and chemical properties to platinum [48–50]. Therefore, we performed in-situ restricted redox growth of Pd@COFs without extra reductants as an ORR catalyst to further investigate its activity. Hence, as a proof of concept, Pd2+ was used to form Pd@WTA-COF (or Pd@WOTA-COF) by soaking a defined amount of COFs in Pd(OAc)2 ethanol solutions, then ultrasonicated for 2 h at room temperature (Fig. 2a). As shown in Fig. S4, the PXRD patterns of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF show that the crystallinity of the COF frameworks is retained after introducing Pd; and the insets of Fig. S4 prove that Pd crystal formed. As shown in Fig. S5, both Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF exhibit lower BET surface area and smaller total pore volume compared with the initial COFs, which may be due to the pores being occupied by Pd NPs. Therefore, the Pd NP loading causes a drastic reduction in the porosity of the COF compared with pristine WTA-COF and WOTA-COF, which inflecting the palladium reduction tended to occur inside the pores and the surface of COFs rather than in the solution. In addition, the TEM images exhibit that Pd NPs uniformly distributed in the 2D-COFs plane for both Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF (Fig. 2f and h). The HRTEM images of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF display-two lattices spacing of ∼0.22 and ∼0.18 nm (Fig. 2g and i), which are attributed to Pd (111) and Pd (200) facets, respectively. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) and corresponding energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) analysis prove the uniform distribution of C, O, and N, while Pd NPs distributed over the Pd@WTA-COF (Fig. 2j, l−n, Fig. S6a and b) and Pd@WOTA-COF matrix (Fig. 2o, q−s, Fig. S6c and d); and the above results further confirmed by EDS line scan (Fig. 2k and p). The above PXRD, EDS, TEM and HRTEM analysis revealed that the Pd NPs with good crystallinity formed without damaging the COFs frameworks. On account of the reductive nature of triarylamine, the Pd NPs can be reduced in the pores of COFs in situ. This in-situ reduction method was supposed to be important to get small and uniform nanoparticles in the pores of COFs, and then promote the homogeneous distribution and accessibility of active sites during the ORR process. In addition, the structural information of the COFs and the state of the complexed palladium have a strong influence on its electrical conductivity and catalytic activity, so the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted to explore the surface electronic properties and chemical state of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF. The typical features of C, N, O or Pd in all four samples are shown in the wide-scan XPS spectra (Fig. S7). For Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF, Pd surface element contents were determined to be 9.38 and 8.77 atom%, respectively (Fig. 3 a). Fig. 3(b) displays the Pd 3d XPS spectra of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF, in which the characteristic peaks at 335.32 eV (Pd 3d 5/2) and 340.60 eV (Pd 3d 3/2) correspond to Pd0, and the other two peaks are attributed to Pd2+ [51–54]. Especially, compared with Pd2+, more Pd0 contents (63.15% for Pd@WTA-COF and 69.41% for Pd@WOTA-COF) proves that the Pd NPs formed successfully. In high-resolution C 1s spectra of WTA-COF and Pd@WTA-COF (Fig. 3c), the peaks located at 284.31, 284.80, 285.55, 286.90 and 290.73 eV are ascribed to C=C, C−C, C−N, C=N bonds and π−π satellite, respectively [55,56]. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the N 1s XPS spectrum for WTA-COF can be deconvoluted to binding energies of 398.56 and 399.39 eV, which are assigned to C−N=C and N−(C)3. However, the binding energies of C−N=C and N−(C)3 for Pd@WTA-COF are 399.24 and 400.09 eV [57,58], which are positively shifted from those of the pristine WTA-COF by 0.68 and 0.70 eV, respectively. For N species, the increase of binding energy is usually ascribed to the reduction of electrons around N. Meanwhile, the high-resolution N 1s spectra of Pd@WTA-COF show an extra peak corresponding to the Pd−N bond appearing at 398.10 eV compared with WTA-COF [59], indicating the interaction between Pd and N. Therefore, the interatomic charge transfer occurred from N to Pd, where the electron-rich configuration around Pd sites may get more moderate binding ability with oxygen to balance the adsorption and desorption for oxygen-containing intermediates during ORR process, then improving the ORR performance [50]. A similar phenomenon is also found in WOTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF systems (Fig. 3e and f). The generality of this inner-pore reduction nucleation methodology for reducing other metal and metal alloy nanoparticles was further demonstrated using other different metal ions under the same synthetic conditions, where the successful preparation of Au@COF, Pt@COF, AuPd@COF, AgPd@COF and PtPd@COF materials can be confirmed by XRD and SEM measurements (Fig. S8–12). For a high-efficiency ORR catalyst, one of the most critical factors is electrical conductivity. Therefore, we further analyzed the conductivity of the as-prepared catalysts, taking the Pd@WTA-COF case as an example, so as to reveal the relationship between the structure and electrical conductivity. As shown in Fig. 3(g), the enhanced electrical conductivity of WTA-COF (∼7.33*10−3 S m−1) was confirmed by electric conduction measurements, which is higher than that of previously reported WTA-COF [47]. The conductivity of WTA-COF-I2 (obtained by treating WTA-COF with I2) is up to 2.15*10−2 S m−1, which is almost three times larger than that of pristine WTA-COF but much lower than that of Pd@WTA-COF, reflecting radical cation, Pd species (including Pd NPs and Pd2+) as well as AcO- (stemmed from Pd(OAc)2) have an influence on the conductivity. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) tests (Fig. 3h) provide radical-forming evidence that both COFs and Pd@COFs gave EPR signals. It is reasonable that the cationic radicals generated in the Wurster-type structure contributed to the high electrical conductivity of the WTA-COF. After encapsulating Pd NPs in WTA-COF, its conductivity is further improved (∼3.2*10−1 S m−1) due to the contribution of metal palladium, which is a benefit to electrocatalytic activities (Fig. 3i). For most pyrolysis-free COFs, the high ORR activity is often restricted byinsufficient electrical conductivity; and the common strategy to solve this problem is adding conductive carbon materials (e.g. carbon black, carbon nanotubes, Ketjenblack etc.). Our in-situ reduction method caused by unique triarylamine structure and high conductivity stemming from cationic radicals inspired us to directly evaluate the ORR activity of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF without the help of other conducting materials. The catalytic activity and stability of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF were tested by rotating ring-disk electrode measurements in 0.1 M KOH solution. For comparison, the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C and 10 wt% Pd/C electrodes were also tested under the same experimental conditions (Fig. S13), where the half-wave potentials (E 1/2) of Pt/C and Pd/C are 0.856 V and 0.760 V, respectively. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the E 1/2 of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF were up to 0.865 V and 0.803 V, and the onset potential was 0.975 V and 0.931 V, evincing its high catalytic activity. It is worth noting that both the limit current density and E 1/2 of Pd@WTA-COF increased after adding 20% Ketjenblack (KB), which is due to the increas conductivity, and the promotion of dissolved oxygen rate in the electrolyte and the adsorption degree of oxygen on the sample surface in the presence of KB. In order to prove the importance of Pd nanoparticles, the ORR activities of pristine WTA-COF and WOTA-COF without the loading of Pd nanoparticles were also investigated. As shown in Fig. S14, both pristine WTA-COF and WOTA-COF exhibit smaller limiting current densities, lower E 1/2, and higher charge transfer resistance (R ct) than that of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF, reflecting Pd NPs was the main active centers. To further quantitatively analyze the reaction kinetic activity of the as-prepared Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF, the Tafel slopes were calculated. As shown in Fig. 4(b), both Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF exhibit a lower linear slope of 39.7 mV dec−1 and 58.5 mV dec−1, indicating favorable reaction kinetics in ORR process. Similar results can be obtained from cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves (Fig. 4c), measured in 0.1 M KOH solution saturated with O2, in which Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF exhibit a significant reaction peak at 0.855 V and 0.812 V, respectively. An average transferred electron number (n) of 3.84 and 3.92 can be determined from the Koutechy–Levich (K–L) plot at different rotation rates from 400 to 2400 r min−1 for Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF, respectively (Fig. 4d–f), signifying a four-electron ORR pathway. Although the electronic conductivity has been proved by the above analysis, the charge transfer rate of electrocatalysts during the catalytic process should be further investigated. Thus, electrochemical impedance spectroscopic (EIS) was carried out to analyze charge transfer resistances (R ct) at 0.8 V. As shown in Fig. 4(g), Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF exhibit a much lower R ct compared with 10 wt% Pd/C, even lower than that of 20 wt% Pt/C, indicating the fast reaction kinetics stemmed from the in-situ reduction process of Pd NPs. In addition to the catalytic activity, the stability of the catalyst is an important basis for evaluating the performance of the catalyst. Firstly, we assessed the resistance to methanol crossover (Fig. 4h), in which the effect of the addition of CH3OH on the polarization current is negligible compared with 20 wt% Pt/C. The chronoamperometric response in Fig. 4(i) displays only ∼6.3% and ∼8.2% decrease of current density at a constant voltage of 0.8 V (vs RHE) over 20,000 s for Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF, respectively, whereas a ∼22% decrease occurred in Pt/C. The accelerated stability test of Pd@WTA-COF was carried out by cycling between 0.6 and 1.0 V versus RHE at 100 mV s−1 for 10, 000 cycles. LSV curve after 10, 000 cycles are shown in Fig. S15, where the E 1/2 and limiting current density are slightly better than the initial one; one reason should be attributed to the enhanced infiltration between the electrolyte and the pores of COFs (activation effect), which is stemmed from the porous nature of wurster-COF. The other reason is that Pd NPs are protected by COFs from being leached and from aggregating during cycling, which is mainly due to the confinement effect of porous wurster-COF on Pd NPs (Fig. S16). Combined with the activation effect and confinement effect during electrochemical testing, the ORR performance of Pd@WTA-COF is slightly improved after CV stabilization. The similar phenomenon is also reported by Gong et. al. [60] Based on the above analysis, it is reasonable to state that the excellent ORR performance of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF stem from their uniformly distributed Pd NPs and high conductivity. It can be observed that the synthesized Pd@WTA-COF shows high E 1/2 and low Tafel slope, and is comparable or even superior to many other Pd-based ORR electrocatalysts (Table S1). It is well-known that a larger electrode area is required for industrial applications of ORR (e.g., H2–O2 Fuel Cells); However, when it grows on the conductive substrate, COF will actually form an insulating layer with high resistance on the surface due to their poor conductivity, which greatly deteriorates their electrocatalytic performance. The high conductivity of Wurster-type COFs can overcome the problem of large-area electrode preparation caused by the lack of conductivity. As a proof-of-concept, carbon cloth (CC, 1 cm × 1 cm) was chosen as the nucleation substrate due to its ability to serve as nucleation sites for many polymers. In order to make COF grow more evenly on the surface of the carbon cloth, we take advantage of the dynamic nature of COF, and use COF as a precursor to growing a uniform COF electrocatalyst thin layer on the surface of the CC through a unique dissolution–recrystallization process (WTA-COF/CC, and WOTA-COF/CC) (Fig. 5 a) [61,62]. To decorate Pd NPs, the prepared WTA-COF/CC and WOTA-COF/CC were immersed in a Pd(OAc)2 acetonitrile solution. As shown in Fig. 5(b and d) and Fig. S17, the SEM images and corresponding EDS mapping of Pd@WTA-COF/CC and Pd@WOTA-COF/CC clearly revealed that large amounts of Pd@COF NPs were deposited on the surface of CC, and and the Pd NPs still grow in situ in the pore of the COF. The EDS elemental mapping images show that Pd was well-distributed over the whole CC (Fig. 5c and e). The ORR performance has been tested for Pd@COF/CC in 0.1 M KOH to extend its application, where the Pd@COF/CC exhibits a large ultimate current density, high E 1/2, faster electron transfer rate, as well as good stability (Fig. 5f–h). In order to show the unique advantage of dissolution–recrystallization process, COFs grew on CC by direct polycondensation of the monomers (Wurster and TA for WTA-COF, or Wurster and (OMe)2TA for WOTA-COF) (Fig. S18a). The SEM images (Fig. S18b and c) verify that WTA-COF and WOTA-COF growth uncontrolled thicker layers composed of nanosheets on the surface of CC. The ORR analysis exhibits an obvious decrease in ultimate current density and E 1/2, indicating that the too-thick COF layer led to a decrease in the electrocatalytic performance (Fig. S18d). To investigate the structure change of electrocatalysts (Pd@WTA-COF, Pd@WOTA-COF, Pd@WTA-COF/CC and Pd@WOTA-COF/CC) after stability tests, we have studied more related structural information after the electrochemical stability test. As illustrated in Fig. S19, the morphology and distribution of elements for Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF are well maintained as evidenced by SEM and corresponding EDS mapping after stability tests. Furthermore, the Pd 3d profiles obtained by XPS measurements reveal that the Pd species on the surface of Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF have not changed significantly before and after the stability test (Fig. S19c and g). In addition, when they are grown on carbon cloth, Pd@WTA-COF/CC and Pd@WOTA-COF/CC also exhibit intact morphology, similar to Pd@WTA-COF and Pd@WOTA-COF (Fig. S20) after the electrochemical stability test. The above confirmed the stability of our electrocatalyst. To demonstrate the practical application of Wurster-typy COF in real zinc-air batteries (ZABs), a primary Zn-air battery was constructed, in which the Pd@WTA-COF (blended with the same weight KB) electrocatalyst-loaded carbon cloth (the mass loading is 1.0 mg cm−2) was used as the air cathode and paired with a zinc plate in 6.0 M KOH (Fig. 6 a). Fig. 6(b) shows that the open-circuit potential of the ZABs employing Pd@WTA-COF as the air cathode was 1.518 V, which is slightly higher than that of battery using commercial Pt/C (1.512 V) as air cathode. The maximum power density of Pd@WTA-COF is as high as 189.7 mW cm−2, which is higher than that of commercial Pt/C (20 wt%) catalyst (152.2 mW cm−2) (Fig. 6d). Moreover, galvanostatic discharging curves (Fig. 6e) demonstrate the rate performance under different current densities ranging from 2 to 50 mA cm−2, where the galvanostatic discharge voltage of Pd@WTA-COF is gradually close to that of Pt/C with increasing current densities; while with the current density being again decreased back, the galvanostatic discharge voltage of Pd@WTA-COF has begun to eclipse that of Pt/C. As shown in Fig. 6(f), the specific capacity of Pd@WTA-COF normalized to the mass of consumed Zn is 770 mA h gZn −1 at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is much higher than that of the Pt/C based battery (672 mA h gZn −1), indicating that Pd@WTA-COF can more effectively utilize the zinc plate in zinc−air batteries compared to Pt/C. In Fig. 6(c), the ZABs using Pd@WTA-COF catalyst on the air electrode can easily power up a light-emitting diode panel, which further proves its feasibility in practical applications. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully constructed and optimized Kagome COFs with predesigned Wurster-type redox sites for confining the growth of palladium NPs. Meanwhile, the Wurster-type unit was oxidized to a radical cation structure, which affords radical cation COFs with conductivity as high as 3.2*10−1 S m−1. Therefore, the Pd@COFs can be used as an ORR electrocatalyst without pyrolysis or additional commercial carbon materials. The Pd@WTA-COF shows excellent electrocatalytic activity toward ORR, showing excellent activities and fast kinetics with a remarkable half-wave potential of 0.865 V, an ultralow Tafel slope of 39.7 mV dec−1, and the lower R ct in alkaline media even in the absence of extra commercial conductive fillers. The high performance for ORR catalysis is attributed to the enhancement of conductivity and uniform Pd NPs in the Kagome COFs. Our work not only provides a facile strategy to directly fabricate metal NPs uniformly distributed in highly conductive COFs with superior electrochemical performance for oxygen reduction; but more importantly, the highly conductive radical cation COFs eliminates the use of carbon filler, thus significantly increasing volumetric activity which is of vital importance for their practical applications. coredata.dc:description: Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have emerged as a class of promising supports for electrocatalysis because of their advantages including good crystallinity, highly ordered pores, and structural diversity. However, their poor conductivity represents the main obstruction to their practical application. Here, we reported a novel synthesis strategy for synergistically endowing a triphenylamine-based COFs with improved electrical conductivity and excellent catalytic activity for oxygen reduction, via the in-situ redox deposition and confined growth of palladium nanoparticles inside the porous structure of COFs using reductive triphenylamine frameworks as reducing agent; meanwhile, the triphenylamine unit was oxidized to radical cation structure and affords radical cation COFs with conductivity as high as 3.2*10−1 S m−1. Such a uniform confine palladium nanoparticle on highly conductive COFs makes it an efficient electrocatalyst for four-electron oxygen reduction reaction (4e-ORR), showing excellent activities and fast kinetics with a remarkable half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.865 V and an ultralow Tafel slope of 39.7 mV dec−1 in alkaline media even in the absence of extra commercial conductive fillers. The generality of this strategy was proved by preparing the different metal and metal alloy nanoparticles supported on COFs (Au@COF, Pt@COF, AuPd@COF, AgPd@COF, and PtPd@COF) using reductive triphenylamine frameworks as reducing agent. This work not only provides a facile strategy for the fabrication of highly conductive COF supported ORR electrocatalysts, but also sheds new light on the practical application of Zn-air battery.

coredata.dc:title: Inner-pore reduction nucleation of palladium nanoparticles in highly conductive wurster-type covalent organic frameworks for efficient oxygen reduction electrocatalysis
